results.content: The course was good and having good content for learning Project reactor apis like Mono and Flux and how to write UT for the same. I would recommend this course for the people who really want to learn Reactive programming using Spring.
results.content_html: The course was good and having good content for learning Project reactor apis like Mono and Flux and how to write UT for the same. I would recommend this course for the people who really want to learn Reactive programming using Spring.

results.content:
The course started off well and provided a good overview of reactive programming in Spring Boot/WebFlux.  However, it became very repetitive as we added controller endpoints, functional endpoints, and their related test cases.  This was okay the first couple of times to see the similarities and differences between them, but quickly became a copy/paste exercise.  I would have liked to see some discussion on when one would prefer controller or router functions over the other since they are both so similar and seem to provide the same capability from a client perspective.  

I liked the section on the streaming end points and Mongo capped collections.  It would have been great to spend more time and depth in this area.  

Lastly, the code examples need some updates.  I would be good to use JUnit 5 / Jupiter style tests.  Also, some of the methods you use from project Reactor are deprecated and should be replaced.
results.content_html:
The course started off well and provided a good overview of reactive programming in Spring Boot/WebFlux. However, it became very repetitive as we added controller endpoints, functional endpoints, and their related test cases. This was okay the first couple of times to see the similarities and differences between them, but quickly became a copy/paste exercise. I would have liked to see some discussion on when one would prefer controller or router functions over the other since they are both so similar and seem to provide the same capability from a client perspective.

I liked the section on the streaming end points and Mongo capped collections. It would have been great to spend more time and depth in this area.

Lastly, the code examples need some updates. I would be good to use JUnit 5 / Jupiter style tests. Also, some of the methods you use from project Reactor are deprecated and should be replaced.

results.content:
This tutorial is really good.  Author gives a lot of information on the subject which is not covered well with other tutorial. 

I like his teaching style as it makes very easy to follow.

results.content: Very much appreciate the in-depth overview at the beginning and jumping into the unit tests to explain the Flux and Mono types was a great move. Coverage of both the Router and RestController techniques for the REST API calls was also excellent. All in all this is a must attend course if you are interested in learning about the Reactive/Asynchronous features of Spring WebFlux.
results.content_html: Very much appreciate the in-depth overview at the beginning and jumping into the unit tests to explain the Flux and Mono types was a great move. Coverage of both the Router and RestController techniques for the REST API calls was also excellent. All in all this is a must attend course if you are interested in learning about the Reactive/Asynchronous features of Spring WebFlux.

results.content: the course is very good. The instructor covers a lot of Spring reactive aspects as he mentioned on the description of the course. It is well organized with a lot of hands-on and theory introduction before to code. The instructor is also responsiveness when we ask some questions on the forum. I liked the way to code because unit test is always used to validate what we are learning. This is a good style. There are some missing lessons on complex queries such as "description contain xxx" or "value is greater than XXX". Although I took about 10 minutes to find in the internet how to implement, I suggest to cover complex queries using spring-webflux. This does not take the score of the course down anyway. Thanks for the course!

There are some missing lessons on complex queries such as "description contain xxx" or "value is greater than XXX". Although I took about 10 minutes to find in the internet how to implement, I suggest to cover complex queries using spring-webflux. This does not take the score of the course down anyway. Thanks for the course!

results.content: The course could be awesome. But unfortunately, right now (10-set-2020), the code taught at the lectures from 71 to 73, does not work at all, some students ask to rapid updating/ask questions for a solution, but the instructor only promise  an future updating for the next weeks. Hence, right now (10-set-2020) is impossible finish the course, coding all examples given in the lectures. This is sad because this course would be "05 stars", once the instructor make some rapid coding updating examples fixing the outdated course parts. Lastly, the students questions should be answered regardless the future updates, otherwise their learning experience will be incomplete, and this is not the actual purpose of the course. IN A NUT SHELL, although the problems above cut off half start, this course deserves, at least, 4.5 start. I highly recommend that.

results.content:
I have enjoyed this course and after finishing it I am confident that I can do something in Spring Webflux. I will rate section wise :
THE BEST PART
----------------
Theory -> 5/5
Coding -> 4/5
Testing -> 5/5 (Very Very Good)
Explanation -> 3.5/5 (Sometimes while writing code, I wish that it would have have been better if explanation is given.)

Few things for improvement :
-----------------------------------
1) Installation guide for different OS for Mongo DB. It is missing.
2) Code update as per latest SpringBoot version.
3) Explain a little more while writing code as why that approach and if there are any other approach which we can take.
results.content_html:
I have enjoyed this course and after finishing it I am confident that I can do something in Spring Webflux. I will rate section wise :
THE BEST PART
----------------
Theory -> 5/5
Coding -> 4/5
Testing -> 5/5 (Very Very Good)
Explanation -> 3.5/5 (Sometimes while writing code, I wish that it would have have been better if explanation is given.)

Few things for improvement :
-----------------------------------
1) Installation guide for different OS for Mongo DB. It is missing.
2) Code update as per latest SpringBoot version.
3) Explain a little more while writing code as why that approach and if there are any other approach which we can take.

results.content: Concepts are not explained well. More focus is on Junit writing which was useful in the initial lectures, but when actual application handson I expected more explanation on concepts at real time. There is no explanation about why an alternate or new method is used. Just simply introducing alternate methods in the coding without any explanation. There is no real time demo about what the reactive web is giving benefit against the non reactive way. It is mostly about seeing somebody coding a reactive web and writing unit test case, no explanation about concepts

results.content:
The lectures gave me quite a good understanding of WebFlux basics. However, it might have been shorter. Too much time is dedicated to a lot of very similar example (one can easily deduce subsequent examples from the previous ones; i.e. if we know how POST works, we don't need to get into the details of PUT. Otherwise, we end up having too many lectures - [GET+POST+PUT+DELETE] times [exchange+retrieve] times [endpoint+junit], etc... It would have been enough to show small differences between these ReST verbs in the endpoints, then one example how it works with exchange and how it works with retrieve, and so on...
On the other hand, more sophisticated topics were omitted. After the course, I still do not know why there are retrieve() and exchange() methods and what are substantial differences between them.
A number of lectures would have been slightly shorter if the lecturer had not recorded his mistakes/errors showing us after a few steps how he corrected them.
Another example - Lecture 23. on Back Pressure; intuitively, the lecturer did what I would do as well - he added ".expectNext(1) " two times as he expected twice to receive a single item. But the example failed with exception stating that the second call should be ".expectNext(2)". The instructor just corrected so, without clarifying why it should be like that.
Similar problem applies to the "multithreaded" Flux. It was not explained what is behind, how it works, when it forks/joins, on what basis, and so on. Just a few examples showing that some work faster and some do not.
results.content_html:
The lectures gave me quite a good understanding of WebFlux basics. However, it might have been shorter. Too much time is dedicated to a lot of very similar example (one can easily deduce subsequent examples from the previous ones; i.e. if we know how POST works, we don't need to get into the details of PUT. Otherwise, we end up having too many lectures - [GET+POST+PUT+DELETE] times [exchange+retrieve] times [endpoint+junit], etc... It would have been enough to show small differences between these ReST verbs in the endpoints, then one example how it works with exchange and how it works with retrieve, and so on...
On the other hand, more sophisticated topics were omitted. After the course, I still do not know why there are retrieve() and exchange() methods and what are substantial differences between them.
A number of lectures would have been slightly shorter if the lecturer had not recorded his mistakes/errors showing us after a few steps how he corrected them.
Another example - Lecture 23. on Back Pressure; intuitively, the lecturer did what I would do as well - he added ".expectNext(1) " two times as he expected twice to receive a single item. But the example failed with exception stating that the second call should be ".expectNext(2)". The instructor just corrected so, without clarifying why it should be like that.
Similar problem applies to the "multithreaded" Flux. It was not explained what is behind, how it works, when it forks/joins, on what basis, and so on. Just a few examples showing that some work faster and some do not.

results.content: O curso consegue dá uma boa visão geral sobre a biblioteca Reactor do Java, porém ele não consegue ir muito além do que é proposto e acaba não aprofundando muito no assunto. O instrutor consegue citar alguns exemplos práticos que consegue ilustrar o porque da utilização da biblioteca, porém novamente bastante genêricos. De ponto positivo ele consegue ilustrar bem a diferença entre a programação reativa vs. implementação padrão (blocking) do modelo REST. Acredito também que a metodologia utilizada não seja tão cativante, deixando poucas atividades para que os alunos executem (ou um projeto) e passando só umas poucas atividades no final do curso.
results.content_html: O curso consegue dá uma boa visão geral sobre a biblioteca Reactor do Java, porém ele não consegue ir muito além do que é proposto e acaba não aprofundando muito no assunto. O instrutor consegue citar alguns exemplos práticos que consegue ilustrar o porque da utilização da biblioteca, porém novamente bastante genêricos. De ponto positivo ele consegue ilustrar bem a diferença entre a programação reativa vs. implementação padrão (blocking) do modelo REST. Acredito também que a metodologia utilizada não seja tão cativante, deixando poucas atividades para que os alunos executem (ou um projeto) e passando só umas poucas atividades no final do curso.
